types.title: Choose the right SSL for your needs
types.description: We offer three types of SSL certificates. Each one provides security, but they differ in scope and verification level.

positive.title: Positive SSL
positive.description: Perfect for personal sites, blogs, and portfolios. Covers one domain.

wildcard.title: Wildcard SSL

ev.title: EV SSL

whatSSLDoes.title: What SSL actually does
whatSSLDoes.description: In plain language, here's what happens when you have an SSL certificate on your website.

encrypts.title: Encrypts information
encrypts.description: When someone fills out a form or logs into your site, SSL encrypts that data so it can't be read by anyone else along the way. It's like sealing a letter in an envelope.

verified.title: Shows you're verified
verified.description: SSL certificates verify that your website is actually yours. Visitors see the padlock icon in their browser, which tells them they're on a legitimate, secure site.

seo.title: Helps with search rankings
seo.description: Google and other search engines favor secure sites. An SSL certificate can help your site rank better in search results. It's become a standard expectation.

whySSL Matters.title: Why SSL matters for your website
whySSL Matters.description: SSL certificates do more than just encrypt data—they're essential for trust, credibility, and search visibility.

trust.title: Builds visitor trust
trust.description: The padlock icon and 'https' in your URL tell visitors their connection is secure. This visual signal builds confidence and reduces bounce rates.

credibility.title: Protects your reputation
credibility.description: Browsers now warn users when sites aren't secure. These warnings can damage your credibility before visitors even see your content.

seo.title: Improves search rankings
seo.description: Google and other search engines prioritize secure sites. SSL is now a ranking factor, meaning secure sites tend to rank higher in search results.

compliance.title: Meets modern standards
compliance.description: Many payment processors and third-party services require SSL. Without it, you may not be able to integrate essential tools for your business.

whenYouNeed.title: When you need SSL
whenYouNeed.description: Here are real situations where SSL matters. If any of these sound like you, you need an SSL certificate.

contactForm.title: You have a contact form
contactForm.description: Even simple contact forms should be secure. When someone shares their email or phone number with you, they trust you to protect it.

sellOnline.title: You sell anything online
sellOnline.description: If you accept payments, process orders, or handle customer accounts, SSL is non-negotiable. It's essential for protecting financial and personal data.

userLogins.title: You have user logins
userLogins.description: Any site where people create accounts and log in needs SSL. Passwords and user data should always be encrypted during transmission.

professional.title: You want to look professional
professional.description: Browsers now warn visitors when a site isn't secure. That warning can hurt your credibility before anyone even reads your content.

sslBasics.title: Understanding SSL basics
sslBasics.description: Key concepts explained without technical jargon:

encryption.title: What is encryption?
encryption.description: Encryption scrambles data so only the intended recipient can read it. When someone submits a form on your site, SSL encrypts that information before it travels across the internet.

certificates.title: What is a certificate?
certificates.description: An SSL certificate is a digital document that proves your website's identity. It's issued by a trusted authority (Certificate Authority) after verifying you own the domain.

https.title: HTTP vs HTTPS
https.description: HTTP is the standard way websites communicate, but it's not secure. HTTPS adds the 'S' for 'Secure'—it uses SSL to encrypt the connection between browsers and your site.

validation.title: Validation levels
validation.description: SSL certificates come in different validation levels. Domain validation (DV) verifies you own the domain. Extended validation (EV) also verifies your business identity, showing your company name in the browser.

notSure.title: Not sure which SSL you need?
notSure.description: That's completely normal. SSL certificates can be confusing, and we'd rather you make the right choice than rush into the wrong one. Talk to us, and we'll help you figure it out.

faq.title: Common questions about SSL
faq.description: These are the questions we hear most often. If yours isn't here, just ask us.

items.question: Do I really need SSL if I'm just starting out?
items.answer: Yes, even from day one. Browsers now show "Not Secure" warnings on sites without SSL, which can scare away visitors before they even see your content. Plus, SSL is now a standard expectation, not a luxury feature. Starting with SSL from the beginning is easier than adding it later.

items.question: Will adding SSL break my existing site?
items.answer: No. SSL doesn't change how your site works—it just encrypts the connection. We help you install it properly, and most modern hosting platforms make the transition smooth. If you run into issues, we're here to help troubleshoot.

items.question: How long does it take to set up?
items.answer: For Positive SSL and Wildcard SSL, setup usually takes a few minutes to a few hours. Extended Validation (EV) SSL takes longer because it involves verifying your organization's identity, which can take 1-3 business days. We guide you through every step.

items.question: What happens when my SSL certificate expires?
items.answer: We'll send you reminders before your certificate expires so you can renew it on time. If it does expire, visitors will see a security warning when they try to access your site. Renewing is simple, and we make sure you don't forget.

items.question: Can I upgrade from one SSL type to another later?
items.answer: Absolutely. Many people start with Positive SSL and upgrade to Wildcard or EV as their business grows. You're never locked into one choice. We make upgrading straightforward when you're ready.

items.question: What exactly does "unlimited subdomains" mean?
items.answer: If your main domain is yourdomain.com, a Wildcard SSL secures anything at *.yourdomain.com—like blog.yourdomain.com, shop.yourdomain.com, app.yourdomain.com, and so on. You can create as many subdomains as you want, and they'll all be covered.

items.question: Does it cover the main domain too?
items.answer: Wildcard SSL covers only subdomains (*.yourdomain.com). If you also want to secure the root domain (yourdomain.com), you'll need to include that as a separate entry or use a multi-domain certificate. We can help you with this setup.

items.question: How is this different from buying individual certificates?
items.answer: If you bought individual SSL certificates for each subdomain, you'd pay for each one separately and manage them all individually. Wildcard SSL bundles them into one certificate, saving you time and money.

items.question: Can I use this for multiple different domains?
items.answer: No. Wildcard SSL covers one domain and its subdomains. If you have multiple separate domains (like yourbusiness.com and anotherbusiness.com), you'll need separate certificates for each.

support.title: Dedicated support
support.description: We guide you through the validation process and help you install your EV SSL certificate properly. The verification process can be complex, and we're here to help at every step.

items.question: How long does the validation process take?
items.answer: Extended Validation typically takes 1-3 business days. The certificate authority needs to verify your business registration, physical location, and contact details. We'll guide you through what documents you need and help speed things along wherever possible.

items.question: What documentation do I need to provide?
items.answer: You'll need proof of business registration (like articles of incorporation or business license), proof of your physical address, and verification that you're authorized to request the certificate on behalf of your organization. Requirements vary slightly by jurisdiction, but we'll walk you through exactly what you need.

items.question: Do I really need EV SSL, or would Positive or Wildcard work?
items.answer: If you're running e-commerce, handling financial transactions, or operating in an industry where trust is critical, EV SSL is worth it. The visible company name makes a real difference in customer confidence. For personal sites or internal tools, Positive or Wildcard SSL are usually sufficient. We can help you decide.

items.question: Can I upgrade from Positive or Wildcard SSL to EV SSL later?
